principles.name: Daily Financial Foundation Reliance
principles.description: 'I go back to the financial foundation almost every day, whether I want to or not.' The accounting/CPA background provides constant practical value regardless of conscious intent to use it.

principles.name: Small Business Owner Knowledge Gap Recognition
principles.description: The accounting foundation is valuable 'because it's knowledge that most small business owners don't have.' This creates a consistent competitive advantage and value proposition.

principles.name: Elevated Status Through Association
principles.description: Working at Arthur Anderson provided 'elevated status' in Cincinnati because 'if you worked there, you had an elevated status.' This early credibility foundation influences ongoing professional positioning.

patterns.name: Financial Foundation as Constant Resource
patterns.description: Leverage financial and accounting knowledge as a daily, automatic resource that provides value even when not consciously deployed.
patterns.context: Business consulting or advisory work where financial literacy provides consistent analytical advantage over business owners who lack this background.

patterns.name: Credibility Through Prestigious Association
patterns.description: Use early association with prestigious organizations (like major accounting firms) to establish ongoing credibility and elevated status in professional relationships.
patterns.context: Professional services where client confidence is influenced by past institutional affiliations and credentials.

examples.name: Accounting Foundation as Daily Tool
examples.content: Dan identifies his 'master's in accounting, CPA, and working at a large public accounting CPA firm' as the foundation he returns to 'almost every day, whether I want to or not.' This knowledge is valuable 'because it's knowledge that most small business owners don't have.'

examples.name: Arthur Anderson Elevated Status
examples.content: Working at Arthur Anderson, 'one of the largest firms in the world,' provided elevated status in Cincinnati where 'if you worked there, you had an elevated status,' establishing early credibility that influences ongoing professional positioning.
